newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Treasuries end narrowly mixed ahead of jobs.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Treasuries end narrowly mixed ahead of jobs.

text.p: The prices of U.S. Treasury securities closed narrowly mixed in very quiet trading before the release of Friday's nonfarm payrolls report.

What little the market had to digest before the 830 EST/1330 GMT release of the report cast a negative spin. Initial jobless claims came in about 12,000 below forecasts and minutes from the Federal Reserve showed its policy-making arm retained a bias toward tightening at its December meeting.
The 30-year long bond ended 1/32 lower at 96-22/32. Its yield was unchanged at 6.76 percent.
A Reuters consensus for the employment report called for the creation of 237,000 payrolls and 5.2-percent jobless rate.

"I keep counseling people to stare past the headline number. I don't know what the Labor Department's problem is, but this number keeps getting goofier in its preliminary form," said Fred Sturm, economist with Fuji Securities Inc.
Sturm said that the gap between the original number and the final revision two months later is so wide as to render the headline number almost meaningless.
The only component he pays attention to, Sturm said, was average hourly earnings -- which also captures the Fed's eye.
Sturm said a reading of unchanged to less in average hourly earnings would be unambiguously bullish, a 1-cent to 5-cent hike neutral and anything above 5 cents bad news.

"You couldn't talk away from a number like that, there's no way around it," he said. More importantly, Sturm said the range of forecasts for the healine number "covered a 40-acre field -- a dead giveaway that nobody knows what's going on."
Sturm saw a neutral headline number leaving the bond market vulnerable to a slight pullback, to levels seen about a week ago when the long bond was yielding 6.85 percent.
"There were no surprises in the FOMC minutes. The Fed continues to preach that patience is a virtue," said Cary Leahey, senior economist at Lehman Government Securities Inc.
Leahey noted that initial jobless claims were weaker than expected and crimped the market somewhat early in the session, before it recovered to levels steady from Wednesday's close.

"A lot of people were taking profits from the big rally we've seen and exiting the market -- setting positions before the payrolls number," Leahey said. "That's pretty much all that happened today -- a downtrade to take advantage of the rally."
Leahey said he expected to see payrolls rise 225,000 given the five-week reporting period.
Chrysler Corp. priced a $500 million century bond as corporate issuance continued strong. However, Hugh Johnson, chief economist at First Albany Corp. said supply was not weighing on the bond market.
"There's substantial liquidity right now. The question is how demanding the borrowers will be," Johnson said.
Payrolls data will set the tone for the bond market for the next three weeks, Johnson said, and he expected Friday's report to contain a number of surprises.
Johnson also expected a 225,000 rise in payrolls and intended to closely watch the average hourly earnings, average workweek and overtime hours components of the report.
"It was quiet today ahead of payrolls as you would expect. This has been an extremely important number for the last 24 months," Johnson said.

Also on Thursday, the two-year note was down 1/32 at 99-30/31 and yielded 5.91 percent; the five-year closed unchanged at 100-4/32 and yielded 6.22 percent, and the 10-year note closed up 1/32 at 100-8/32 to yield 6.46 percent.
(( -- N.A. Treasury desk. 212-859-1663 ))
